passages.text:
You decide to analyze the proxy traffic for any clicks. At 11:00 AM, your analysis revealed that several employees clicked the phishing link, and three entered credentials — including one with IT admin privileges. Leadership requests an immediate update:

“How many accounts are compromised, and what are we doing about it?”

What is your next step?

choices.text: Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies
choices.next: Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies

choices.text: Take no action since the emails are already blocked
choices.next: Take no action since the emails are already blocked

passages.text:
You block the sender IP, successfully preventing future attacks from this same IP. However, employee credentials are still at risk from suffering similar attacks by different actors.

How will you prevent future attacks?

choices.text: Enforce MFA on employee accounts where available
choices.next: Enforce MFA on employee accounts where available

choices.text: Require the use of a password manager
choices.next: Require the use of a password manager

passages.id: Check with HR about recent hires
passages.text: You decide to contact HR and ask about any recent hires that match the users credentials. They notify you that there is no current employee under the name you provided. You investigate this user further and find that they have signed on incredibly recently.

passages.id: Close the incident as a false positive
passages.text:
You decide to close the incident and flag it as a false positive in the system. Later that day, however, multiple employees report being locked out after “resetting” their passwords using the phishing link. You now realize that the link was a positive alert which you have now reported to the CISO 

What should you do?

choices.text: reset passwords to see if it was a system error
choices.next: reset passwords to see if it was a system error

passages.text: At 9:36 AM, you receive an alert that a mass phishing campaign is targeting employees. The emails appear to come from the CFO, urging users to “change their passwords immediately” using a link provided.

choices.text: Run AV scans on all network devices
choices.next: Run AV scans on all network devices

passages.id: Continue about your day since the passwords have been fully reset
passages.text:
You decided to continue about your day since passwords have been fully reset for all the affected users. However, later that week, it is discovered that a threat actor, has not only breached the system, but has exfiltrated company and customer sensitive data. In order to find out what went wrong, your company decided to perform an audit, and security log analysis to understand what was done in response or if anything had been detected. It was found that the user you decided to ignore, was actually a newly created account by the threat actor and that was the reason for the breach. Due to your lack of proper procedures, the company was breached resulting in a class action lawsuit against the company. You have been terminated. 
⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⡟⢡⡾⠋⠉⠀⠄⢈⣿⠸⠿⠿⢿⣿⡏⢸⣿⣷⡌⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿

⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⢀⠀⠂⠀⢠⡀⠂⠌⠠⠁⠐⢀⠴⠀⠠⠠⠀⠀⠀⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿
KA(truncated...)

passages.id: Dismiss this as normal user activity (file downloads of customer data are typical for your company
Enforce MFA on employee accounts where available
passages.text:
By immediately implementing MFA company-wide, you have successfully rendered all previously stolen credentials useless and prevented a major breach. The incident is contained and mitigated. Your CISO, and the CEO of The Overdraft Emporium, were extremely impressed with your quick, forward thinking suggestions, has given you a promotion to Manager of the SOC team. Congratulations! 
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⡀⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠈⠄⠄⠄⠁⠄⠁⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⣀⣀⣤⣤⣴⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣦⣤⣤⣄⣀⡀⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⣴⣿⣿⡿⣿⢿⣟⣿⣻⣟⡿⣟⣿⣟⡿⣟⣿⣻⣟⣿⣻⢿⣻⡿⣿⢿⣷⣆⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢘⣿⢯⣷⡿⡿⡿⢿⢿⣷⣯⡿⣽⣞⣷⣻⢯⣷⣻⣾⡿⡿⢿⢿⢿⢯⣟⣞⡮⡀⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢸⢞⠟⠃⣉⢉⠉⠉⠓⠫⢿⣿⣷⢷⣻⣞⣿⣾⡟⠽⠚⠊⠉⠉⠉⠙⠻⣞⢵⠂⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢜⢯⣺⢿⣻⣿⣿⣷⣔⡄⠄⠈⠛⣿⣿⡾⠋⠁⠄⠄⣄⣶⣾⣿⡿⣿⡳⡌⡗⡅⠄⠄
'⠄⠄⠄⢽⢱⢳⢹⡪⡞⠮⠯⢯⡻⡬⡐⢨⢿⣿⣿⢀⠐⡥⣻⡻⠯⡳⢳⢹⢜⢜⢜⢎⠆⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠠⣻⢌⠘⠌⡂⠈⠁⠉⠁⠘⠑⢧⣕⣿⣿⣿⢤⡪⠚⠂⠈⠁⠁⠁⠂⡑⠡⡈⢮⠅⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠠⣳⣿⣿⣽⣭⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣺⣟⣾⣻⣿⣯⢯⢿⣳⣶⣶⣶⣖⣶⣮⣭⣷⣽⣗⠍⠄⠄
Available(truncated...)

You isolate the login times and see which accounts were affected. Now you need to determine the source and full scope.

[[Investigate email sender]]

You are a SOC Analyst at The Overdraft Emporium. A mid-size regional financial institution known for its friendly service but relaxed approach to internal cybersecurity protocols. The company values efficiency and dislikes “unnecessary interruptions.” 

[[Continue]]

You investigate the link contained in the emails in a sandbox environment. The page mimics your company’s password reset site, but the domain is slightly off, colors are wrong, and some links are broken — clear signs of phishing. 

[[Analyze proxy traffic for clicks.]]

You've traced the email back to a disposable foreign server. You now need to understand the payload. 

[[Investigate email contents]]

passages.id: Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies

passages.text:
You open the link in a sandboxed environment.

The page mimics your company’s password reset site, but the domain is slightly off, colors are wrong, and some links are broken — clear signs of phishing.

What is your next step?

[[Quarantine the emails for investigation]] 
[[Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies]]

choices.text: Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies
choices.next: Monitor the accounts quietly for anomalies

passages.text:
You quickly quarantine all suspicious emails from employee inboxes and mark the incident as active. You prepare for deeper analysis. 

[[Review SIEM and SSO logs.]]
[[Analyze proxy traffic for clicks.]]
[[Identify impacted accounts.]]
[[Investigate email contents]]

passages.id: Remove new user and block their IP
passages.text:
You decided to remove the new user and block their IP. You then draft an email and send it to your CISO, explaining what had happened, what you had discovered, and what steps you had taken to remediate. Your CISO, and the CEO of The Overdraft Emporium, were extremely impressed with your quick, forward thinking suggestions, has given you a promotion to Manager of the SOC team. Congratulations! 
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄

⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠈⠄⠄⠄⠁⠄⠁⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄⣀⣀⣤⣤⣴⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣦⣤⣤⣄⣀⡀⠄⠄⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⠄⣴⣿⣿⡿⣿⢿⣟⣿⣻⣟⡿⣟⣿⣟⡿⣟⣿⣻⣟⣿⣻⢿⣻⡿⣿⢿⣷⣆⠄⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢘⣿⢯⣷⡿⡿⡿⢿⢿⣷⣯⡿⣽⣞⣷⣻⢯⣷⣻⣾⡿⡿⢿⢿⢿⢯⣟⣞⡮⡀⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢸⢞⠟⠃⣉⢉⠉⠉⠓⠫⢿⣿⣷⢷⣻⣞⣿⣾⡟⠽⠚⠊⠉⠉⠉⠙⠻⣞⢵⠂⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢜⢯⣺⢿⣻⣿⣿⣷⣔⡄⠄⠈⠛⣿⣿⡾⠋⠁⠄⠄⣄⣶⣾⣿⡿⣿⡳⡌⡗⡅⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠄⢽⢱⢳⢹⡪⡞⠮⠯⢯⡻⡬⡐⢨⢿⣿⣿⢀⠐⡥⣻⡻⠯⡳⢳⢹⢜⢜⢜⢎⠆⠄⠄
⠄⠄⠠⣻⢌⠘⠌⡂⠈⠁⠉⠁⠘⠑⢧⣕⣿⣿⣿⢤⡪⠚⠂⠈⠁⠁⠁⠂⡑⠡⡈⢮⠅⠄⠄
Available(truncated...)

passages.id: Require the use of a password manager
passages.text:
Your employees now remember their passwords all the time. However, their credentials are still just as exposed. Since you failed to properly protect employee credentials, another threat actor has breached the company through an admin's account. This causes a loss for the company and a demotion for you to enter security awareness training. 

[[End-loss]]

You decided to reset the password of all the compromised accounts, potentially preventing access from the actors. However, how future proof is this? How will you prevent and contain incidents like these in the future?

choices.text: Enforce MFA on employee accounts where available
choices.next: Enforce MFA on employee accounts where available

passages.text:
You review SSO logs and find the first logon from a new user. You query SIEM logs for user activity during this time. During this review, you find that the user had downloaded a document and upon opening the document, it is discovered that the document contained sensitive customer data.
What is your next step?

choices.text: Dismiss this as normal user activity (file downloads of customer data are typical for your company
choices.next: Dismiss this as normal user activity (file downloads of customer data are typical for your company

choices.text: Remove new user and block their IP
choices.next: Remove new user and block their IP

passages.id: Run AV scans on all network devices
passages.text:
After running AV scans, you determine that all devices on the network are free of malware. What do you do next? 

[[Close the incident as a false positive]]

choices.text: Close the incident as a false positive
choices.next: Close the incident as a false positive

passages.id: Take no action since the emails are already blocked
passages.text:
Despite blocking the phishing emails, the stolen credentials are still valid. Attackers gain access to finance systems, leading to unauthorized wire transfers by evening. 

[[End-loss]]

passages.id: reset passwords to see if it was a system error
passages.text:
You decide to reset the affected users passwords and are under the impression that all is resolved. However while reseting users passwords you discover a user you do not recognize. What should you do?

[[Continue about your day since the passwords have been fully reset]]
[[Delete the user]]
[[Check with HR about recent hires]]

choices.text: Continue about your day since the passwords have been fully reset
choices.next: Continue about your day since the passwords have been fully reset
